Name: Accountability?
Definition: The "capability of a product to enable actions of an entity to be traced uniquely to the entity" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 404), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 404). See ISO 7498-2:1989

Name: Accuracy
Definition: A "qualitative assessment of correctness" or "quantitative measure of the magnitude of error" (IEEE, 2013, p. 7)

Name: Adaptability
Definition: The "capability of a product to be effectively and efficiently adapted for or transferred to different hardware, software or other operational or usage environments" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of flexibility (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of flexibility (ISO/IEC, 2023a) or at the very least related (IEEE, 2017, p. 12), as well as of replaceability (ISO/IEC, 2023a). Inclusivity and user assistance can improve this (and flexibility), and this can improve user assistance and interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Analyzability (IEEE, 2017, p. 18) or Analysability (ISO/IEC 2023a)
Definition: The "capability of a product to be effectively and efficiently assessed regarding the impact of an intended change to one or more of its parts, to diagnose it for deficiencies or causes of failures, or to identify parts to be modified" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar in Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10) and related to modifiability (IEEE, 2017, p. 18)

Name: Appropriateness Recognizability
Definition: The "capability of a product to be recognized by users as appropriate for their needs … from initial impressions of the product or system and/or any associated documentation" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Related to usability (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), originally as a sub-quality (ISO/IEC, 2011), which has an associated test type
Notes: Related to usability (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), originally as a sub-quality (ISO/IEC, 2011), and a sub-quality of interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a). Potentially a synonym for understandability (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), although I disagree

Name: Authenticity
Definition: The "capability of a product to prove that the identity of a subject or resource is the one claimed" (ISO/IEC 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of security (IEEE, 2017, p. 404), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of security (IEEE, 2017, p. 404). See ISO/IEC 13335-1:2004

Name: Behavioral Compatibility
Definition: "Identical behavior of two objects" (IEEE, 2017, p. 43; OG IEEE, 2009)
Notes: Subset of compatibility?

Name: Changeability
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of modifiability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) which is a sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of modifiability (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Cohesion
Definition: The "manner and degree to which the tasks performed by a single software module are related to one another" (IEEE, 2017, p. 74)
Notes: Has the following subcategories: "coincidental, communicational, functional, logical, procedural, sequential, and temporal" (IEEE, 2017, p. 74); also called "module strength" and related to coupling (IEEE, 2017, p. 74)

Name: Comfort
Definition: The "degree to which the user is satisfied with physical comfort" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Probably more oriented towards hardware systems, but may include screen brightness, colour constrast, volume levels, etc.

Name: Complexity
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component has a design or implementation that is difficult to understand and verify" (IEEE, 2017, p. 81)
Notes: A quality that software shouldn't have; constrasted with simplicity. Has the subcategory of "functional" (IEEE, 2017, p. 193)

Name: Conciseness
Definition: The degree to which functions are implemented "with a minimum amount of code" (IEEE, 2017, p. 88)

Name: Concurrency
Definition: The "property of a system in which events can occur independently of each other, and hence are not ordered" (IEEE, 2017, p. 88; OG ISO/IEC, 2004)

Name: Confidentiality
Definition: The "capability of a product to ensure that data are accessible only to those authorized to have access" (ISO/IEC 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 375), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 375)

Name: Connectivity
Definition: The "capability of a system or device to be attached to other systems or devices without modification" (IEEE, 2017, p. 93; OG ISO/IEC, 2015; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: See ISO 2382

Name: Context Coverage
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system can be used with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in both specified contexts of use and in contexts beyond those initially explicitly identified"
Notes: Has the sub-qualities context completeness and flexibility (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Context Completeness
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system can be used with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in all the specified contexts of use" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Implies the existence of a "completeness" supercategory, but is a sub-quality of "context coverage" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Continuity (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-7)
Precedence for Test Approach: Given as a type of hardware testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 21), which would make this an out-of-scope test approach

Name: Correctability
Definition: The "degree of effort required to correct software defects and to cope with user complaints" (IEEE, 2017, p. 104)
Notes: Related to maintainability/modifiability (and if so, implies testing type)?

Name: Coupling
Definition: The "manner and degree of interdependence between software modules" or "how closely connected … [they] are" (IEEE, 2017, p. 107)
Notes: Has the following subcategories: "common‐environment", "content", "control", "data" (or "input‐output" (IEEE, 2017, p. 114)), "hybrid", and "pathological" (IEEE, 2017, p. 107). A related idea, "decoupling", seems to refer to a process rather than a quality (IEEE, 2017, p. 124)

Name: Cross-Browser Compatibility
Definition: "The degree to which a website or web application can function across different browsers and degrade gracefully when browser features are absent or lacking" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of compatibility, which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of compatibility

Name: Dependability
Definition: The "trustworthiness of a computer system such that reliance can be justifiably placed on the service it delivers" (IEEE, 2017, p. 127; OG IEEE, 2005)
Precedence for Test Approach: Performance testing exists, which may be a superset of this (IEEE, 2017, p. 127; OG ISO/IEC, 2013)
Notes: Related to "availability performance and its influencing factors" (IEEE, 2017, p. 127; OG ISO/IEC, 2013)

Name: Diversity
Definition: The (amount/degree of?) "realization of the same function by different means" (IEEE, 2017, p. 143)
Notes: "Software diversity" is described as a "software development technique … with the intent of providing error detection, increased reliability, additional documentation, or reduced probability … [of] programming or compiler errors" (IEEE, 2017, p. 421). See also "homogeneous redundancy" (IEEE, 2017, p. 207)

Name: Effectiveness
Definition: The "accuracy and completeness with which users achieve specified goals" (ISO/IEC, 2011; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Related to efficiency (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). See ISO 9241

Name: Expandability
Definition: The "degree of effort required to improve or modify software functions' efficiency" (IEEE, 2017, p. 173)
Notes: Related to extendability (IEEE, 2017, p. 173)

Name: Extendability
Definition: The "ease with which a system or component can be modified to increase its storage or functional capacity" (IEEE, 2017, p. 174)
Notes: Also called "extensibility"; related to expandability, flexibility, and maintainability (IEEE, 2017, p. 174)

Name: Faultlessness
Definition: The "capability of a product to perform specified functions without fault under normal operation" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of reliability (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of availability (IEEE, 2017, p. 38), reliability, and dependability; can also be applied to other qualities (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Freedom from Risk
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system mitigates the potential risk to economic status, human life, health, or the environment" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Has sub-qualities that are different varities of "risk mitigation": economic, health and safety, and environmental (ISO/IEC, 2011); these seem more like functional attributes than qualities

Name: Functional Appropriateness
Definition: The "capability of a product to provide functions that facilitate the accomplishment of specified tasks and objectives" while "excluding any unnecessary steps" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of functional suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: Synonym of suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; see ISO 9241-110l; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) "for the task" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; see ISO 9241-110). A sub-quality of functional suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Functional Completeness
Definition: The "capability of a product to provide a set of functions that covers all the specified tasks and intended users' objectives" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of functional suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of functional suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) and potentially completeness?

Name: Functional Correctness
Definition: The "capability of a product to provide accurate [and precise] results when used by intended users" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of functional suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of functional suitability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) and a synonym of accuracy (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), although the latter seems incomplete. Possible tradeoff between achieving fully and automating, at least in some contexts (Berdine et al., 2006, p. 116)

Name: Functional Safety
Definition: "The absence of unreasonable risk due to hazards caused by malfunctioning behavior of Electric/Electronic(E/E) - Systems" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of safety, which may have an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of safety, but sometimes considered a synonym (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). See ISO 26262

Name: Generality
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component performs a broad range of functions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 197)
Notes: Related to reusability (IEEE, 2017, p. 197)

Name: Immunity
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system is resistant to attack" (IEEE, 2017, p. 214; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Related to integrity (IEEE, 2017, p. 214)

Name: Inclusivity
Definition: The "capability of a product to be utilised by people of various backgrounds … [including] people of various ages, abilities, cultures, ethnicities, languages, genders, economic situations, education, geographical locations and life situations" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of accessibility (renamed to "interaction capability") (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Integrity
Definition: The "capability of a product to ensure that the state of its system and data are protected from unauthorized modification or deletion either by malicious action or computer error" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Part of build verification testing is "validat[ing] the integrity of each new build" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, pp. 375, 404), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, pp. 375, 404) and related to immunity (IEEE, 2017, p. 231)

Name: Interaction Capability
Definition: The "capability of a product to be interacted with by specified users to exchange information between a user and a system via the user interface to complete the intended task" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Prerequisite for usability (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: "Focus[es] on a set of attributes that enable interaction by users (or operators) to complete specific tasks in a variety of contexts of use", vs. usability, which "focuses on outcomes of use to determine whether tasks are achieved by users with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specific context of use" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; see ISO/IEC 25019), although the latter seems to still be present in some sub-qualities (e.g., user assistance) (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Learnability
Definition: The "capability of a product to have specified users learn to use specified product functions within a specified amount of time" (ISO/IEC, 2023a) or a product or system's "suitability for learning" (IEEE, 2017, p. 249)
Precedence for Test Approach: Originally a sub-quality of usability (ISO/IEC, 2011), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a). See ISO 9241‐110

Name: Manageability
Definition: The "degree to which IT infrastructure management can attain and keep an application in its operational state" (IEEE, 2017, p. 262; OG ISO/IEC, 2015)
Notes: "Involves the transparency and manageability of applications from an infrastructure point of view" (IEEE, 2017, p. 262)

Name: Maturity
Definition: The "degree to which a system, product or component meets needs for reliability under normal operation" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of reliability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10; ISO/IEC, 2011; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of reliability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10; ISO/IEC, 2011; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). Replaced with "faultlessness" by ISO/IEC (2023a)

Name: Migratability
Definition: The "ability to change the configuration, substituting one reference point of an object for another while the object is being used"(IEEE, 2017, p. 276; OG ISO/IEC, 2009)
Notes: This definition is worded weirdly. Related to portability (IEEE, 2017, p. 276)

Name: Modifiability
Definition: The "capability of a product to be effectively and efficiently modified without introducing defects or degrading existing product quality" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar in Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10; IEEE, 2017, p. 280; OG IEEE, 2015; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), which has an associated test type
Notes: Synonym of changeability (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). A sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10); also related to analyzability and modularity (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 280)

Name: Modularity
Definition: The "degree to which a system … is composed of discrete components such that a change to one component has minimal impact on other components" (IEEE, 2017, p.  281; similar in Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10 with a more vague definition of "independent" and ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10). Related to the idea of low coupling, high cohesion, and modifiability (IEEE, 2017, p. 281)

Name: Non-Repudiation
Definition: The "capability of a product to prove that actions or events have taken place, so that the events or actions cannot be repudiated later" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 404), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 404). See ISO 7498-2:1989

Name: Operability
Definition: The "capability of a product to have functions and attributes that make it easy to operate and control" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Originally a sub-quality of usability (ISO/IEC, 2011), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) and "related to controllability, user error robustness and conformity with user expectations" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; see ISO 9241-110)

Name: Permanence
Definition: The "degree to which failures can affect object state changes due to completed transactions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 320; OG ISO/IEC, 2009)

Name: Pleasure
Definition: The "degree to which a user obtains pleasure from fulfilling their personal needs" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Precision
Definition: The "degree of exactness or discrimination with which a quantity is stated" (IEEE, 2017, p. 331)
Notes: A sub-quality of correctness (ISO/IEC, 2023)

Name: Presentability
Definition: The ability to "be retrieved and viewed" (IEEE, 2017, p. 333; OG IEEE, 2015)

Name: (Product) Quality
Definition: The "degree to which the product satisfies stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 345; OG ISO/IEC, 2012)

Name: Readability
Definition: The "ease with which a system's source code can be read and understood, especially at the detailed, statement level" (IEEE, 2017, p. 367)

Name: Replaceability
Definition: The "capability of a product to replace another specified product for the same purpose in the same environment" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar in IEEE, 2017, p. 377)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of flexibility (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of flexibility (ISO/IEC, 2023a). Can reduce lock-in risk (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Resistance
Definition: The "capability of a product to sustain operations while under attack from a malicious actor" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of security (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Resource Utilization
Definition: The "capability of a product to use no more than the specified amount of resources to perform its function under specified conditions" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of performance efficiency (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type, as well as another sub-quality (capacity) (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: A sub-quality of performance efficiency (ISO/IEC, 2023a). Hamburg and Mogyorodi (2024) say it's a synonym of "storage", but this seems incomplete

Name: Reusability
Definition: The "degree to which an asset can be used in more than one system, or in building other assets" (IEEE, 2017, p. 387; OG 2010; similar in ISO/IEC, 2023a and Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10) and related to generality (IEEE, 2017, p. 387)

Name: Satisfaction
Definition: The "degree to which user needs are satisfied when a product or system is used in a specified context of use" or "the user’s response to interaction with the product or system" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Has the following sub-qualities: usefulness, trust, pleasure, comfort; "includes attitudes towards use of the product" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Self-Descriptiveness
Definition: The "capability of a product to present appropriate information … to make its [objectives, properties (IEEE, 2017, p. 407),] capabilities and use immediately obvious to the user without excessive interactions with a product or other resources[,] … includ[ing] user documentation, help desks, [and] other users" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: A subquality of interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) and related to "maintainability, testability, usability" (IEEE, 2017, p. 407) and potentially learnability and the idea of being self-documented?

Name: Service Availability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-7)
Notes: Related to availability? A subset?

Name: Service Continuity
Definition: The "capability to deliver a service without interruption, or with consistent availability as scheduled and agreed" (IEEE, 2017, p. 411)
Notes: A sub-quality of continuity? Related to service availability?

Name: Simplicity
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component has a design and implementation that is straightforward and easy to understand" (IEEE, 2017, p. 414)
Notes: Contrasted with complexity (IEEE, 2017, p. 414)

Name: Survivability
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system continues to fulfill its mission by providing essential services in a timely manner in spite of the presence of attacks" (IEEE, 2017, p. 450; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Related to recoverability (IEEE, 2017, p. 450)

Name: Testability
Definition: The "degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which test criteria can be established … and tests can be performed to determine whether those criteria have been met" (IEEE, 2017, p. 473; OG ISO/IEC, 2014); "the effort … [required] to test the modified software" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Precedence for Test Approach: Part of build verification testing is verifying the testability "of each new build" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), which has an associated test type
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)

Name: Time Behaviour
Definition: The "capability of a product to perform its specified function under specified conditions so that the response time and throughput rates meet the requirements" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Sub-quality of performance efficiency (ISO/IEC, 2023a), which has an associated test type, as well as another sub-quality (capacity) and a potential sub-quality of this (response time) (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: A sub-quality of performance efficiency (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Traceability
Definition: The "degree to which a relationship can be established between two or more products of the development process" (IEEE, 2017, p. 481; OG ISO/IEC, 2012) or "to which each [software] element … establishes its reason for existing" (IEEE, 2017, p. 481; OG ISO/IEC, 2010)
Notes: Can be aided with the use of a traceability matrix (IEEE, 2017, p. 482). See IREB

Name: Trust
Definition: The "degree to which a user or other stakeholder has confidence that a product or system will behave as intended" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Unambiguity
Definition: The degree to which something is "described in terms that only allow a single interpretation" (IEEE, 2017, p. 488; OG IEEE, 2015)
Notes: Applicable to software, or just documentation?

Name: Understandability
Definition: The "ease with which a system can be comprehended at both the system‐organizational and detailed‐statement levels" (IEEE, 2017, p. 489)
Notes: More general than readability and applicable to the system as a whole (IEEE, 2017, p. 489)

Name: Usefulness
Definition: The "degree to which a user is satisfied with their perceived achievement of pragmatic goals, including the results of use and the consequences of use" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: User Assistance
Definition: The "capability of a product to be used by people with the widest range of characteristics and capabilities [including "language differences and disabilities associated with age, sight, hearing, use of hands, arms and legs"] to achieve specified goals in a specified context of use" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Originally a sub-quality of usability (ISO/IEC, 2011) and now a sub-quality of accessibility (renamed to "interaction capability") (ISO/IEC, 2023a), both of which have associated test types
Notes: A sub-quality of accessibility and interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a). See ISO/IEC 25019

Name: User Engagement
Definition: The "capability of a product to present functions and information in an inviting and motivating manner encouraging continued interaction" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: A sub-quality of interaction capability and related to pleasure and satisfaction (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: User Error Protection
Definition: The "capability of a product to prevent operation errors" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Precedence for Test Approach: Originally a sub-quality of usability (ISO/IEC, 2011) and potentially related to robustness, both of which have associated test types
Notes: A sub-quality of interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) and potentially related to robustness

Name: User-Friendliness?
Definition: The degree to which a system is easy and convenient to use (IEEE, 2017, p. 498)
Notes: Difference between this and usability?

Name: Variability?
Definition: The degree of "differ[ence] among members of the product line" (IEEE, 2017, p. 500; OG ISO/IEC, 2015)

Name: Verifiability
Definition: The degree to which something "can be checked for correctness by a person or tool" (IEEE, 2017, p. 503; OG 2013)
